claim: King Henry is reaching for a dagger in the Portrait of Henry VIII.

supporting.text: In the Portrait of Henry VIII, his hand is positioned near his belt where a dagger would typically be worn, suggesting an intentional gesture.

attacks.text: In the Portrait of Henry VIII, his hand is positioned near his belt where a dagger would typically be worn, suggesting an intentional gesture.
The positioning of the hand near the belt could simply be a standard pose for portraits of the time, not necessarily indicating a dagger.
Historical records do not mention Henry VIII carrying a dagger in this portrait, casting doubt on the interpretation.
Artistic conventions of the period often depicted hands near the belt as a sign of authority, not necessarily weaponry.
The absence of explicit mention does not preclude the presence of a dagger, as not all details are documented.

supporting.text: Historical records indicate that Henry VIII often carried a dagger as part of his royal attire, making it plausible that the portrait depicts this detail.

attacks.text: Historical records indicate that Henry VIII often carried a dagger as part of his royal attire, making it plausible that the portrait depicts this detail.
Portraits of monarchs often idealize or omit details for symbolic or aesthetic reasons, so the absence of a dagger in the painting does not confirm its presence.
The angle of Henry VIII's hand in the portrait does not clearly show a dagger, making the claim speculative.
Art historians have noted that royal portraits from this era frequently included symbolic objects, so the absence of a dagger could be intentional.
Detailed analysis of the portrait's brushwork suggests no hidden or obscured objects, including a dagger.
Symbolic objects in portraits were often depicted prominently, not subtly, further undermining the claim of a hidden dagger.
